School of Chemical Engineering & Technology Tianjin University Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemical Science and Chemical Engineering (Tianjin) Tianjin 300072 China Graphical abstract The development of environmentally friendly nonmercuric catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination reaction mainly focuses on precious metal like Au, Pd and Ru. Non-precious metal based catalyst had much lower activity and stability in this reaction, limiting its practical application. In this work, a novel ionic liquid improved Cu-based heterogeneous catalyst has been designed and successfully synthesized, and it showed the highest catalytic activity and stability among the reported non-precious metal based catalyst used in the reaction of acetylene hydrochlorination. Among many ionic liquids, the (Methoxymethyl) triphenylphosphonium chloride (MOMTPPC) ionic liquid improved Cu-based heterogeneous catalysts has the highest catalytic performance. The optimal 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC achieved the conversion of C2H2 of 92.2% under the reaction condition of T=180℃, GHSV (C2H2) of 180 h−1 and V HCl/V C2H2 = 1.2. And under the industrial GHSV (C2H2) of 36 h−1, C2H2 conversion maintains above 98.7% within 360 h. A series of experimental characterizations combined with theoretical calculations indicated that the addition of MOMTPPC ionic liquid can inhibit carbon deposition, prevent the aggregation of Cu species, enhance the dispersion of Cu species and the adsorption of HCl reactant. The stabilization effect of MOMTPPC to Cu is mainly through the hydrogen bond, steric hindrance of MOMTPPC cation and electrostatic effect. The development of Cu@MOMTPPC/SAC catalyst with high efficiency shed light on the potential of replacing the toxic mercuric catalyst with non-precious Cu-based catalyst in the polyvinyl chloride (PVC) industry. Keywords Non-Precious metal Acetylene hydrochlorination Cu-based heterogeneous catalyst Ionic liquid Catalytic mechanism 1 Introduction The most important chemical process in coal rich region (like China) for the production of vinyl chloride monomer (VCM) of PVC is acetylene hydrochlorination reaction [1,2]. The traditional mercury chloride catalysts used in the reaction of acetylene hydrochlorination is highly toxic and volatile, causing serious harmness to both workers and environment [2–5]. In the year of 2013, 139 countries signed “the Minamata Convention on Mercury” to inhibit the trade and application of mercuric product throughout the world before 2020 [6]. Therefore, it’s urgent to develop green, cheap and novel mercury-free catalysts. In 1975, Shinoda [7] synthesized a series of activated carbon supported metal chloride catalysts and a correlation between the conversion of acetylene to vinyl chloride and the electron affinities of metal ions was found. In 1985, Hutchings [8] analyzed Shinoda’s work and inferred that the catalytic activity for the hydrochlorination of acetylene to vinyl chloride correlates significantly with the standard reduction potential of metal cations for supported metal chlorides catalysts. Then the activity order of precious metal (Au > Pd > Ru > Ir > Pt > Rh) further confirmed this inference [9]. After that, many researchers have done remarkable work to develop precious mercury-free catalysts such as Au [1,4,10,11], Pd [12–14], Ru [15,16], Rh [17] for acetylene hydrochlorination. The outstanding catalytic performance for Au [1,4] and Ru [15] made them promising catalysts for further industry utilization. But the industry application of precious metal catalysts may be restricted by its high cost [3,18]. Thus, the study of non-precious metal catalyst is also of vital importance. Based on the work of Shinoda [7] and Hutchings [9,19], copper chloride is supposed to be a potential non-precious catalyst to replace the toxic mercuric catalyst in acetylene hydrochlorination due to its moderate standard electrode potential [8], low toxicity and good thermostability. Many researches have been carried out to promote its catalytic performance. Wei et al [20] synthesized nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (NCNTs) supported CuCl2 catalyst and found the obvious interaction between CuCl2 and NCNTs. The acetylene conversion on 5%Cu-NCNTs could maintain about 45% within 3 h under the reaction condition of 180 ℃, C2H2 gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) = 180 h−1, HCl/C2H2 feed volume ratio (V HCl/V C2H2) = 1.1. Dai et al [21] reported that the Cu-g-C3N4/AC catalyst could obtain an acetylene conversion of 79% within 450 min under the condition of 180 ℃, GHSV (C2H2) = 72 h−1, V HCl/V C2H2 = 1.15. Liu et al [22] found that 13X molecular sieve could enhance and stabilize the catalytic performance of CuCl2 and the 25%Cu/13X catalyst could achieve an acetylene conversion of 78% under the condition of 220℃, GHSV (C2H2) = 36 h−1. The above work mainly focused on the catalytic activity and their reaction time are all less than 16 h. Li et al [23] synthesized a series of phosphoric acid modified Cu/SAC catalysts. After calcination, the optimal 2.5CuP/SAC catalyst could achieve an acetylene conversion of 70% under the condition of 140 ℃, GHSV (C2H2) = 180 h-1, V HCl/V C2H2 = 1.1. During the lifetime test under 30 h-1, the conversion of acetylene could maintain above 95% on 2.5CuP/SAC catalyst but it deactivated fast after 80 h, and at the same reaction, the Cu/SAC catalyst deactivated quickly from 99% to 73% in 100 h. These reports confirmed the catalytic activity of copper-based catalyst, but the catalytic activity is not very excellent and it is easily to be deactivated which is mainly caused by the carbon deposition covered on active sites [24,25]. The intrinsic reason was that copper catalyst had a very strong ability to activate acetylene rather than HCl, resulting in the activated acetylene would polymerize to cover the active sites [26]. Therefore, the key to inhibit carbon deposition and improve the catalytic performance is to design a synergistic copper-based catalyst which can activate both HCl and C2H2 efficiently at the same time to produce VCM. Ionic Liquids (ILs) possess unique physicochemical properties including high solubility, high thermal stability and negligible volatility [27,28]. Due to their unique properties, ILs have offered great potential for developing clean catalytic technology [29]. Many reports showed that ILs had very high solubility of HCl gas [30–32], which was even higher than in water. The high solubility of HCl in ILs was not only caused by the physical adsorption but also induced by the chemical adsorption of HCl, which showed the potential of IL to activate the HCl in the reaction of acetylene hydrochlorination. In fact, ILs have been used as the solvent for homogeneous catalysts to improve the catalytic performance for the reaction of acetylene hydrochlorination [33,34], such as HAuCl4, H2PtCl6, MnCl2 dissolved in imidazolium ILs [35], and Pt, Au, Pd stabilized in anionic surfactant carboxylate ionic liquids [36]. Besides, some ILs have also been induced as additive to modify the heterogeneous catalysts such as supported Au-[Primim]Cl/AC catalyst [37] and Au-Cu-[Primim]Cl/AC catalyst [11]. For example, our previous study [15] showed that TPPB IL can significantly enhance the catalytic performance of supported Ru-based catalyst in the reaction of acetylene hydrochlorination via TPPB improving the dispersion of Ru species, suppressing the reduction of active Ru species and inhibiting the carbon deposition during the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction. The key point for the IL application in the mercury-free catalysts is that certain IL matches certain metal chloride catalyst. For example, the TPPB IL which is good for Ru-based catalyst may not be good for the Cu-based catalyst. The addition effect of the certain IL mainly depends on the interaction of the IL with the active metal species and the support, which is determined by the structural and electronic match. Recently, Zhang et al [38] modified CuCl with N-methylpyrrolidonium hydrochloride ionic liquid and Li et al [39] modified CuCl2 with [PrMIm]Cl ionic liquid and both of them are used them in acetylene hydrochlorination with homogeneous reaction system. The system of CuCl with N-methylpyrrolidonium hydrochloride, the higher catalytic performance system, can achieve an acetylene conversion of 88% at the condition of 160 ℃, GHSV (C2H2) = 30 h−1, V HCl/V C2H2 = 1.2, whose operation condition is lower than the industrial GHSV (C2H2) = 36 h−1. It’s worth noting that acetylene hydrochlorination reaction in the industry is always designed as heterogeneous system. The heterogeneous catalytic systems have the merits of easy to separate, easy to scale up and easy to recycle [40,41]. Supported ionic liquid catalysts (SILC) combined the merits of homogeneous system and heterogeneous systems which showed the prospect of non-mercuric acetylene hydrochlorination [42]. In this work, we tried to design and develop a non-precious Cu-based heterogeneous catalyst with high efficiency in the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction via IL modification. The ILs with different functional groups have great influence on the catalytic performance of Cu-based catalyst. Among those ILs, we found that the addition of (Methoxymethyl) triphenylphosphonium chloride (MOMTPPC) IL has the greatest improvement for the catalytic performance of Cu/SAC, which induced the conversion of C2H2 increasing from 65% to 92.2% under the reaction condition of T  = 180℃, GHSV (C2H2) of 180 h−1 and V HCl/V C2H2 = 1.2. A series of experimental characterizations combined with density functional theory (DFT) calculations was carried out to disclose the promotion effects of MOMTPPC to copper catalyst as well as the interaction mechanism between them. The Cu@MOMTPPC/SAC has the highest C2H2 conversion and good stability compared with the reported non-precious mercury-free catalysts, which is a strong candidate to replace the cheap but toxic mercury catalyst used in the reaction of acetylene hydrochlorination and promote the sustainable development of PVC industry. 2 Experimental and theoretical methods 2.1 Chemicals SAC (20–40 mesh) was purchased from Shanghai Carbosino Material Co., Ltd. CuCl2 (purity 99.0%), CuCl (purity 99.0%) and Ethanol (purity 99.7%) was purchased from Tianjin Fengchuan Chemical Reagent Science and Technology Co., Ltd. Hydrochloric acid (purity AR) was purchased from Huanghua Shijikebo Science and Technology Development Co., Ltd. (Methoxymethyl) triphenylphosphonium chloride (MOMTPPC), acetonyltriphenylphosphonium chloride (ACMTPPC), (cyanomethyl)triphenyltriphenylphosphonium chloride (CNMTPPC), tetraphenylphosphonium bromide (TPPB) and tetraphenylphosphonium chloride (TPPC) were purchased from Shanghai D&B Biological Science and Technology Co., Ltd. The C2H2 (99.99%) and HCl (99.99%) gases were purchased from Tianjin Dong Xiang Gases Distribute Co., Ltd. 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts Prior to catalyst synthesis, the spherical activated carbon support was washed by 65 wt% HCl solution at 60 ℃ for 6 h to remove impurities followed by filtration with deionized water until the filtrate was neutral. Then it was dried at 120℃ for 12 h to obtain the clean SAC support. The Cu@MOMTPPC/SAC catalysts were synthesized by an excessive volume impregnating method. Taking the 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC catalyst as an example, firstly, the CuCl2 was dissolved in 10 ml deionized water and 1.5 g of MOMTPPC was dissolved in 10 ml ethanol, then they were quantitatively mixed under agitating to serve as precursor. Next, 10 g SAC was added to the precursor under agitating for 20 min. Then it was sealed and incubated under 60℃ for 12 h followed by drying under 120 ℃ for 12 h to obtain the 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC. The Cu loading amount was fixed at 15 wt% unless mentioned. Then the 15%Cu@5%MOMTPPC/SAC, 15% Cu@10%MOMTPPC/SAC, 15% Cu@20%MOMTPPC/SAC, 15% Cu@15%ACMTPPC/SAC, 15% Cu@15%CNMTPPC/SAC, 15% Cu@15%TPPC/SAC, 15% Cu@15%TPPB/SAC catalysts could be obtained. The copper and MOMTPPC complexes were synthesized by slowly evaporating the precursor obtained from mixture of 5%, 10% and 15% CuCl2 with 15%MOMTPPC to obtain sepia powder of 5% Cu-15%MOMTPPC, 10% Cu-15%MOMTPPC and 15% Cu-15%MOMTPPC. The single crystal of C40H40Cl4CuO2P2 was synthesized by the following method. Firstly, 0.5 mmol (0.0861 g) of CuCl2·2H2O was dissolved in 0.6 ml of hydrochloric acid. And 1.0 mmol (0.3498 g) of MOMTPPC in 2 ml propan-2-ol was added to the CuCl2 solution and heated. The solution was diluted with methyl-tertiary-butyl-ether (MTBE) to obtain orange crystal which was further used to elucidate the interaction mode of copper chloride and MOMTPPC. The structural information was analyzed by single-crystal XRD. Additional characterization data can be found in the Supporting Information. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a X’Pert Pro Panalytical diffractometer with monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (40 mA, 40 kV, 10 min from 5 to 75°). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were recorded on ESCALAB 250Xi (Thermo fisher Scientific) using an Al Kα monochromated (150 W, 20 eV pass energy, 500 μm spot size). All binding energies are referenced to the C (1 s) binding energy of surface carbon contamination at 284.8 eV. Low temperature adsorption/desorption experiments were recorded on Quantachrome Instruments autosorb analyzer system. The catalysts were degassed for 6 h at 170℃ and measured at -196 ℃ under liquid nitrogen atmosphere. Specific surface area and pore volume were determined by Brunner − Emmet − Teller (BET) method. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments were measured on AutoChem BET TPR/TPD (Quantachrome Instruments AMI-90) instrument to determine the adsorption capacity of reactants and product in catalyst. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a METTLER TOLEDO TGA/DSC 2 instrument to detect carbon deposition amount of catalysts and thermostability of synthesized sepia powder. High Resolution Transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and Transmission electron microscopy(TEM)mapping were recorded on the JEM-2100 F equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectroscope (EDS). The samples were grinded and dispersed in ethanol then dropped on a 300 mesh Mo grid. Fourier transform infrared spectrometry (FTIR) was performed on a Bruker Vertex70 FT-IR spectrophotometer with a resolution of 4 cm−1. Organic element analysis was conducted on Vario EL III instrument. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were recorded at 9.79 GHz (X-band) with a Bruker CW Elexsys E 500 spectrometer at 180 °C. The spectra were simulated with the experimental parameters using Bruker Xsophe. The total content of Cu in catalysts were determined by Optima 5300DV inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES). 2.4 Catalyst performance test The acetylene hydrochlorination on different catalysts were performed in a fixed-bed flow microreactor (i.d. 10 mm). CKW-1100 temperature controller produced in the Chao Yang Automation Instrument Factory (Beijing, China) was applied to control the reaction temperature. Before reacting, the microreactor containing 5 ml of catalyst was purged by nitrogen to remove impurities of water and air. The reactant of hydrogen chloride was fed into reactor to activate catalyst under 180 ℃ for 30 min, then the reactant of acetylene was fed into the reactor to start reaction and the reaction pressure was 1 atm. The gas flow in the reaction was controlled by the mass flow controller and the C2H2 gas hourly space velocity (GHSV (C2H2)) was 180 h−1 (36 h-1 for lifetime test) with a HCl/C2H2 feeding volume ratio (V HCl/V C2H2) of 1.2. The reaction temperature was 180 °C. The reaction effluents were passed into NaOH solution and analyzed by gas chromatography (GC-2014C). 2.5 Simulation details All DFT calculations were performed using Dmol3 module in the Materials Studio software package. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew‐Wang (PW91) [43] functional was employed to describe the exchange and correlation term. The DNP basis was chosen as the basis set and the all-electron-core treatment were performed in all of the calculations. A smearing of 0.008 Ha to the orbital occupation was applied to achieve accurate electronic convergence. The convergence tolerance of energy, maximum force and maximum displacement for geometry optimization were chosen to be less than 1.0 × 10−5 Ha, 0.002 Ha/ Å and 0.005 Å, respectively. The adsorption energy (E ads) of the reactants and product on the catalyst together with support were defined by the following equation: (1) E ads = E ads-state - E adsorbate - E substrate where E ads-state was the total energy of adsorbed systems, E adsorbate was the total energy of adsorbate and E substrate was the total energy of catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance Considering the balance of activating HCl and C2H2, different ILs were introduced to copper catalyst aiming to improve its activity and stability. The catalytic performance was evaluated under the condition of 180 ℃, GHSV (C2H2) of 180 h−1 and V HCl/V C2H2 = 1.2. As shown in Fig. 1 a and 1b, the initial acetylene conversion on 15%Cu/SAC, 15%Cu@15%TPPC/SAC, 15%Cu@15%TPPB/SAC, 15%Cu@15%CNMTPPC/SAC, 15%Cu@15%ACMTPPC/SAC and 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC is 65%, 72.1%, 73.2%, 88.9%, 90.4% and 92.2%, respectively. And the selectivity to VCM is above 99.5% on these catalysts except 15%Cu@15%TPPC/SAC and 15%Cu@15%TPPB/SAC catalysts. The catalytic activity of the 15%Cu/SAC catalyst decreased quickly during the 48 h reaction, further demonstrating that the main problem for copper catalyst is the low activity and fast deactivation. After the addition of IL, the activity and stability of copper catalysts are both improved. Although TPPB and TPPC ILs are both excellent promoter for ruthenium catalyst in this reaction [15], their improvement for the catalytic performance of copper catalysts is very limited compared with the MOMTPPC, ACMTPPC and CNMTPPC ILs, indicating the addition effect of IL on Cu-based catalyst may be different with that of Ru-based catalyst in the reaction of acetylene hydrochlorination. In the following part, we take the best performed MOMTPPC ionic liquid as an example to investigate the promotion effect of ionic liquid to copper catalysts. The 15%Cu@MOMTPPC/SAC catalysts with different MOMTPPC IL loading amount were prepared and their catalytic performance are shown in Fig. 1c. By increasing the MOMTPPC content from 5% to 20%, the acetylene conversion on 15%Cu@MOMTPPC/SAC catalysts can achieve 87.9%, 90.3%, 92.2%, 91.2%, respectively, demonstrating that the 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC catalyst has the best catalytic performance. The initial activity for 15%MOMTPPC/SAC (without CuCl2) is only 5% higher than pure SAC support, while C2H2 conversion on 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC catalyst is 27.2% higher than that on 15%Cu/SAC, which may be caused by the synergistic effect between Cu active species and MOMTPPC IL. The lifetime of 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC was also tested under the condition of 180 ℃, GHSV (C2H2) of 36 h−1 and V HCl/V C2H2 = 1.2. As shown in Fig. 1d, the conversion of C2H2 increases to 99.5% in 15 h and maintains above 98.7% within 360 h. The selectivity remains above 99% during the lifetime testing. Considering that the reaction temperature and GHSV (C2H2) have very great influence on the acetylene conversion, the 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC catalyst in this work performs the highest catalytic activity and best stability compared with the previous reported copper-based catalysts in acetylene hydrochlorination reaction (listed in Table S1). The efficient Cu@MOMTPPC/SAC catalyst shed light on the potential of substituting toxic mercuric catalyst with non-precious Cu-based catalyst in the PVC industry. 3.2 Carbon deposition analysis Carbon deposition is an important reason for the deactivation of catalyst in acetylene hydrochlorination reaction, especially for copper catalysts [25,26]. TG analysis was conducted to determine the amount of carbon deposition on different catalysts after 48 h reaction. As shown in Fig. 2 , all the fresh and used catalysts show a slight weight loss before 100 ℃, which is attributed to the evaporation of the adsorbed water on the catalyst. Afterwards, there is an obvious weight loss in 100–300 ℃ because of the carbon deposition on the surface of the support [44]. When the temperature is higher than 300 ℃, there appears a sharp mass decrease due to the burning of MOMTPPC and SAC. The carbon deposition amount on the catalyst surface after 48 h reaction was calculated from TG profiles via the precise method [45]. The carbon deposition on 15%Cu/SAC catalyst is as high as 10.61%. When MOMTPPC IL is induced into the Cu-based catalyst from 5% to 20%, the carbon deposition amount decreases gradually and the 15%Cu@20%MOMTPPC/SAC achieves the lowest carbon deposition amount of 3.42%. The TGA results demonstrated that the addition of MOMTPPC IL can effectively inhibit the carbon deposition and greatly improve the stability of Cu-based catalyst. 3.3 Structural improvement Aiming to determine the effect of MOMTPPC IL on the pore structure of the support, low temperature adsorption/desorption experiment was performed and the results are shown in Table 1 . The specific surface area and the pore volume are gradually reduced by increasing the loading amount of MOMTPPC IL. This decrease could mainly be attributed to the adsorption of IL on the surface of the SAC support and the dilutive effect with the addition of MOMTPPC [46]. The loss of the specific surface area during the reaction is probably attributed to the carbon deposition on the catalyst surface which could result in the decrease of catalytic activity [47]. For the used MOMTPPC added Cu-based catalyst, the decrease of the specific surface area was greatly inhibited during the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction, which further demonstrates that the addition of MOMTPPC IL could effectively resist the formation of carbonaceous material on the catalyst surface. And it’s worth noting that though the ΔS BET of 15%Cu@20%MOMTPPC/SAC catalyst is the lowest, but its activity is not as good as 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC catalyst, which can be attributed to the blocking of pore structure in SAC support by an excess of MOMTPPC. The TEM-EDS analysis was applied to confirm the dispersion enhancement in the 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC catalyst. As shown in Fig. 3 , the element mapping of C, O, P, Cl, Cu indicates a uniformly distribution of them on the SAC support. The overlapping of C and Cu in Fig. 3g shows the homogeneous dispersion of copper species. And the overlap of Cu and P (Fig. 3i) shows that MOMTPPC IL can disperse homogeneously around Cu on the support. The HRTEM images of 15%Cu/SAC and 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . For 15%Cu/SAC, the lattice fringes of 0.242 nm and 0.285 nm are corresponding to the (11-2) planes of CuCl2 (JCPID: 35-0690) and the (111) planes of CuCl (JCPID :30-0472), respectively. Whereas for the HRTEM image of 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC, it shows a much larger lattice fringe of 0.467 nm. Many researches show that a larger lattice fringe can be obtained when adding IL to CuCl2 to form Cu containing IL complex crystal [48–50]. Therefore, the MOMTPPC IL may chemically interact with Cu species to form a new crystal structure and enhance the dispersion of the active species. As shown in Fig. 5 , the XRD analysis was performed to detect the aggregation morphology of 15%Cu/SAC and 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC catalysts before and after 48 h reaction. It can be seen that the peaks of the fresh 15%Cu/SAC catalyst are the same to the amorphous state characteristic peaks of SAC at 23° and 43.5° and no peaks corresponding to Cu species are detected, which further demonstrates that the Cu species were dispersed over the SAC support and the particle sizes are rather small. While for the used 15%Cu/SAC catalyst, the obvious diffraction peaks at 16.1°, 32.2° and 39.6° are newly appeared, which can be indexed with CuCl2 structure (JCPID: 35-0690), indicating the aggregation of CuCl2 particles during the reaction. The aggregation of the active species is also one of the reasons for catalyst deactivation [51]. When MOMTPPC IL is added into the Cu-based catalyst, only the diffraction peaks of SAC are observed both in the fresh and used 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC catalysts, implying that the addition of MOMTPPC IL can effectively inhibit the aggregation of copper species during the reaction. The ICP results showed that the Cu content in the fresh and used 15%Cu/SAC is 14.39 wt% and 12.11 wt%, whereas it in fresh and used 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC is 14.58 wt% and 14.50 wt%. The loss ratio of Cu in 15%Cu/SAC and 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC after 48 h reaction is 15.84% and 0.55%, respectively. The comparison clearly shows that the addition of MOMTPPC IL can improves the catalyst stabilization and prevents the loss of copper species during the reaction. 3.4 Electronic improvement Hutchings et al reported that Cu+ and Cu2+ showed almost the same catalytic performance for acetylene hydrochlorination reaction [8,9,18,20,52,53]. In order to investigate the effect of MOMTPPC IL on the electronic properties of Cu active species, the XPS measurement was performed and the valence states of Cu 2p2/3 on fresh and used 15%Cu/SAC and 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC catalysts are shown in Fig. 6 . As the peak fitting, peak at 934.0–934.7 eV could be attributed to the Cu2+ species [54,55]. And peak at 932.0–932.6 eV could be attributed to Cu+ species [55]. The relative contents of surface Cu+ and Cu2+ in fresh 15%Cu/SAC are 44.7% and 55.3%, respectively. Some reports also showed that the CuCl2 was partly reduced to Cu+ species during the preparation process [56]. The relative contents of surface Cu+ and Cu2+ in fresh 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC are 47.7% and 52.3%, respectively. The molar ratio of Cu+/Cu2+ in both fresh catalysts almost keeps at 1:1, indicating the addition of MOMTPPC IL does not change the ratio of Cu+/Cu2+ during the catalyst preparation process. After 48 h reaction, the relative content of surface Cu2+ increases to 68.3% in the used 15%Cu/SAC. During the reaction, the HCl reactant has oxidization and aggregation effect of metal chloride in supported catalysts [57,58], causing the oxidization of Cu+ to Cu2+ as well as the aggregation of CuCl2. The aggregation effect would further induce the loss of metal chloride [59], which was demonstrated by the above XRD and ICP results. Whereas in the used 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC catalyst, the molar ratio of Cu+/Cu2+ is still around 1:1, indicating that the MOMTPPC IL can greatly stabilize the copper species during the reaction thus the stability of catalyst is enhanced. 3.5 Interaction mechanism The above-mentioned catalytic performance tests show that MOMTPPC IL can greatly enhance the activity and stability of the copper catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination. The corresponding experimental characterization results reveal that the addition of MOMTPPC can enhance the dispersion of copper species, stabilize the valance states of copper active species, inhibit the aggregation of CuCl2 as well as prevent the copper loss during the reaction. But the deeper question is: how can MOMTPPC achieve these good effects? It mainly depends on the interaction between MOMTPPC IL and Cu species. In this section, we conducted a series of characterizations and DFT calculations to further reveal the interaction mechanism. Because the SAC support has very strong masking effect on FTIR characterization, the 15%Cu-15%MOMTPPC system without support are used here. As shown in Fig. 7 , peaks at 3056, 2993, 2958 and 2937 cm−1 which can be attributed to the stretching vibration of C–H bonds in IL decreases dramatically [60,61]. The red shift shows the stretch of C–H bond in IL, which can be attributed to the interaction of Cl in CuCl2 with H in C–H bond, and the whole system is stabilized due to the formation of hydrogen bonds. By comparing the peaks in MOMTPPC and 15%Cu-15%MOMTPPC in 650-1650 cm−1, peak at 1110 cm−1 can be ascribed to the stretching vibration of COC in methoxymethyl [62,63]. It moves to 1114 cm−1 which can be attributed to the inductive effect of electrophilic Cl in CuCl2 with H in HCO bond in methoxymethyl. It implies the possible interaction between Cl in CuCl2 with H of methoxymethyl in IL. These results indicate the existence of hydrogen bond between Cl in CuCl2 with H of C–H bond in IL as well as with H of HCO in IL. In order to further confirm the strong interaction between copper and ionic liquid, a series of copper chloride and MOMTPPC complex was synthesized by evaporating the precursor solution of 5%Cu-15%MOMTPPC, 10%Cu-15%MOMTPPC and 15%Cu-15%MOMTPPC. TGA was conducted to determine the thermostability of the obtained sepia powder. As shown in Fig. 8 , the decomposition temperature of different powder increases from 147.95 ℃ of pure MOMTPPC to 194.20 ℃ of 15%Cu-15%MOMTPPC. The thermostability enhancement demonstrates the strong chemical interaction between MOMTPPC and copper chloride. The single-crystal XRD analysis supplies the structure of copper chloride and MOMTPPC IL complex when the mole ratio of CuCl2 and MOMTPPC is 1:2, which is shown in Fig. 9 . It can be seen that the CuCl2 forms two additional Cu-Cl bonds with Cl of MOMTPPC thus Cu atom is coordinated with four Cl atoms (CuCl4 2−) to form tetrahedral geometry, which is further demonstrated via EPR analysis (as shown in Figure. S1). The interaction between copper chloride and MOMTPPC is through the H in MOMTPPC (especially the H in methoxymethyl) and the Cl in copper chloride anion. As shown in Fig. 9, the bond length of hydrogen bond between CuCl4 2− and H in benzene ring of MOMTPPC cation is 2.943 Å, and the bond length of hydrogen bonds between CuCl4 2− and H in methoxymethyl of MOMTPPC are 2.832 Å (C adjacent to P) and 2.735 Å (C away from P), respectively, which shows the H atoms in methoxymethyl have stronger interaction between Cl of CuCl4 2−. Further details of single-crystal XRD results can be found in the supporting information (Table S2 and S3). The formation of tetrahedral CuCl4 2− structure verifies the strong chemical interaction observed in TG characterization of Cu-15%MOMTPPC. And the visualization of hydrogen bond between CuCl4 2− and MOMTPPC cation further verifies the FTIR results. It can also be concluded that the stabilization and dispersion of copper is through the hydrogen bonds, the steric hindrance of MOMTPPC cation due to its large size and electrostatic effect between ionic liquids cation and copper chloride anions. The stability of Cu species on carbon support improved by MOMTPPC IL is further demonstrated via DFT calculations. Firstly, the structure parameter of MOMTPPC was calculated. As shown in Figure S2, the distance between anion Cl− and three different H atoms in the cation are 2.370 Å, 2.130 Å and 2.419 Å, respectively. The results show the hydrogen bonds between anion and cation in the MOMTPPC IL, indicating the rationality of IL module used in the DFT calculations. As shown in Fig. 10 a, the adsorption energies of both CuCl2 and CuCl on carbon support without MOMTPPC IL are -72.31 kJ mol−1 and −165.07 kJ mol−1, respectively. After adding MOMTPPC IL, the adsorption energies are greatly increased to -188.43 kJ mol-1 and -294.31 kJ mol−1, respectively. The improvement of the stability of CuCl2 and CuCl on carbon support are mainly contributed to the strong interaction between Cu species and MOMTPPC IL (the adsorption structure of CuCl2 on carbon support with and without MOMTPPC IL is shown in Figure S3). Since carbon supports usually have many functional groups which may have the effect on the catalytic reactivity, the carbon support with both acidic and alkaline function groups were considered here and the adsorption results are shown in Fig. 10b. Without MOMTPPC IL, the existence of functional groups (whatever acidic or alkaline) on the carbon support surface enhanced the stability of CuCl2 to some extent. When the MOMTPPC IL is induced into the catalyst system, the stability improvement of CuCl2 is mainly determined by the MOMTPPC IL and the effect of the functional groups on the support surface is not obvious. 3.6 Reaction mechanism It had been confirmed that Cu+ and Cu2+ had almost the same catalytic performance of acetylene hydrochlorination reaction. It is also commonly considered that the carbon deposition on metal catalysts is attributed to the polymerization of activated C2H2 due to the insufficient activation of HCl. In order to disclose the interaction between catalysts and HCl, C2H2 and VCM, a series of DFT calculations as well as HCl-TPD and VCM-TPD were carried out. Fig. 11 and Figure S4 shows the adsorption energies and adsorption configurations of HCl, C2H2 and VCM on supported CuCl and CuCl2 catalysts. It can be seen that both supported CuCl and CuCl2 together have the highest adsorption energy for C2H2 compared with HCl and VCM. After C2H2 adsorbed on supported CuCl and CuCl2 catalysts, the line structure of C2H2 is destroyed and the CC bond length is increased from 1.202 Å (in free state of C2H2) to 1.242 and 1.236 Å, respectively. When the activated C2H2 reactant could not react with HCl in time, they may polymerize with each other to form coke deposition on the catalyst surface, resulting in the decrease of active sites and deactivation of the catalysts [25]. When the MOMTPPC IL is added into the catalyst system, the adsorption energy of HCl on both supported CuCl and CuCl2 catalysts are greatly increased by 15.55 and 16.89 kJ mol−1, respectively. And the HCl is further activated with H-Cl bond length increasing from 1.324 and 1.323 Å on CuCl/SAC and CuCl2/SAC to 1.363 and 1.351 Å on CuCl@MOMTPPC/SAC and CuCl2@MOMTPPC/SAC, respectively (shown in Figure S5). The results show that it is beneficial to the HCl adsorption and activation via adding MOMTPPC IL to Cu-based catalysts. The HCl-TPD results shown in Figure S6a further confirms the enhanced adsorption ability of HCl with the addition of MOMTPPC IL. To further understand the enhancement effect of HCl adsorption, Mulliken charge analysis was carried out [64]. Before adding MOMTPPC IL, HCl gets 0.052 e from CuCl2/SAC catalyst as the electron acceptor, resulting in the activation of HCl. Moreover, HCl can gets 1.788 times electrons (0.093 e) from CuCl2@MOMTPPC/SAC catalyst than CuCl2/SAC catalyst and HCl is further activated. The activation of HCl is conductive to the heterolytic cleavage process through increasing the molecular polarity [16,65,66]. The polarity of the H-Cl bond increases from 0.407 in gas phase to 0.630 in CuCl2/SAC catalyst. When adding MOMTPPC IL, HCl is further polarized with HCl bond polarity of 0.723. Thus, the effectively activated HCl is much easier to add with C2H2 to form VCM, which is in accord with previous work [15,67]. The trend of electron transfer for the adsorbed HCl on CuCl@MOMTPPC/SAC catalyst are the same to that on CuCl2@MOMTPPC/SAC catalyst. For the C2H2 reactant, the addition of MOMTPPC IL does not change the activation ability of supported CuCl catalyst, whereas the adsorption energy of C2H2 on supported CuCl2 catalyst decreases by 15.97 kJ mol−1. Similarly, the adsorption energy of VCM on CuCl/SAC and CuCl@MOMTPPC/SAC catalysts were barely changed, whereas the adsorption energy of VCM on CuCl2@MOMTPPC/SAC decreases by 13.32 kJ mol−1, which make the VCM product easily to be desorbed from the catalyst. The VCM-TPD results (as shown in Figs. 5b) also show that the desorption ability of 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC for VCM is much better than that of CuCl2/SAC catalyst. The Mulliken charge analysis in Table S4 show that the transfer direction of the electrons between the adsorbate (C2H2 and VCM) and the supported CuCl2 catalyst is even changed after adding MOMTPPC IL. Without MOMTPPC IL, both C2H2 and VCM donate electrons to CuCl2 and the carbon support, whereas they get a little bit electrons from the carbon support after adding MOMTPPC IL. Thus, the addition of MOMTPPC IL into the CuCl2 catalyst reduces its activation ability for C2H2 and increases the desorption ability for VCM product, which effectively inhibit the coke deposition at source. The adsorption of HCl, C2H2 and VCM on CuCl2@MOMTPPC/SAC with both acidic and alkaline functional groups catalysts were also calculated, as shown in Figure S7. The results show that functional groups have little influence on the adsorption of reactants and product. 4 Conclusion We developed supported Cu@MOMTPPC catalysts as the highly active and stable low-cost catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination reaction. Among the five kind ionic liquid, the optimal 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC shows superior activity with the conversion of C2H2 of 92.2% under the reaction condition of T =180 ℃, GHSV (C2H2) of 180 h−1 and V HCl/V C2H2 = 1.2. The selectivity of catalysts remains above 99.0% during reaction. And under the typical industrial acetylene hydrochlorination reaction condition, C2H2 conversion maintains above 98.7% within 360 h of lifetime testing operation. Through a series of catalysts characterization, including TGA, ICP-AES, TEM-EDS, XRD and XPS, the improving effects of MOMTPPC reflect in inhibiting coke deposition, reducing the loss of copper species, enhancing the dispersion of copper species, preventing the aggregation of CuCl2 and stabilizing the valence states of copper active species. Detailed study of FTIR and Single-Crystal structure characterizations shows that the interaction between MOMTPPC and Cu is mainly through the formation of hydrogen bond, the steric hindrance of MOMTPPC cation and electrostatic effect between copper chloride anion and MOMTPPC cation. Further DFT calculations reveal that the addition of MOMTPPC can not only enhance the stability of Cu species on the support, but also improve the activation of HCl reactant as well as the desorption of VCM product. The high activity and stability of 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC shows the potential for its further industrial application in the reaction of acetylene hydrochlorination. coredata.dc:description: The development of environmentally friendly nonmercuric catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination reaction mainly focuses on precious metal like Au, Pd and Ru. Non-precious metal based catalyst had much lower activity and stability in this reaction, limiting its practical application. In this work, a novel ionic liquid improved Cu-based heterogeneous catalyst has been designed and successfully synthesized, and it showed the highest catalytic activity and stability among the reported non-precious metal based catalyst used in the reaction of acetylene hydrochlorination. Among many ionic liquids, the (Methoxymethyl) triphenylphosphonium chloride (MOMTPPC) ionic liquid improved Cu-based heterogeneous catalysts has the highest catalytic performance. The optimal 15%Cu@15%MOMTPPC/SAC achieved the conversion of C2H2 of 92.2% under the reaction condition of T=180℃, GHSV (C2H2) of 180 h−1 and V HCl/V C2H2 = 1.2. And under the industrial GHSV (C2H2) of 36 h−1, C2H2 conversion maintains above 98.7% within 360 h. A series of experimental characterizations combined with theoretical calculations indicated that the addition of MOMTPPC ionic liquid can inhibit carbon deposition, prevent the aggregation of Cu species, enhance the dispersion of Cu species and the adsorption of HCl reactant. The stabilization effect of MOMTPPC to Cu is mainly through the hydrogen bond, steric hindrance of MOMTPPC cation and electrostatic effect. The development of Cu@MOMTPPC/SAC catalyst with high efficiency shed light on the potential of replacing the toxic mercuric catalyst with non-precious Cu-based catalyst in the polyvinyl chloride (PVC) industry.
coredata.dc:title: MOMTPPC improved Cu-based heterogeneous catalyst with high efficiency for acetylene hydrochlorination
